Question: What must be provided by Union or Member State law for processing personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures?
Option B: Urgent processing for national security reasons
Option C: Appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects
Option D: Mandatory reporting to the Data Protection Authority

Question: Under which Article of the GDPR is a controller exempt from maintaining, acquiring or processing additional information to identify a data subject?
According to the GDPR, when a controller is unable to identify a data subject for the purpose of exercising the data subject's rights, what must the controller do?
Option B: Request additional information from the data subject
Option C: Inform the data subject accordingly, if possible

Question: Which of the following articles will not apply to a data subject if the data subject is not identifiable in certain situations?
If a controller is unable to identify a data subject, for what purpose may the controller maintain, acquire or process additional information?
Option A: For the sole purpose of complying with this Regulation
Option B: For the purpose of exercising the data subject's rights
Option C: Only when necessary to provide the data subject with information
Option D: In circumstances where data subject has consented to the processing

Question: Under what conditions may Articles 15 to 20 still apply to a data subject who is not identifiable?
Option A: When the data subject provides additional information enabling their identification
Option B: When the data subject withdraws their consent
Option C: When the controller receives additional information from a third party
Option D: When the controller is able to identify the data subject through public records

Question: What measures shall the controller take to provide information to the data subject under Articles 13 and 14?
Option A: The controller shall provide the information orally, without any electronic means.
Option B: The controller shall provide the information in writing, using clear and plain language, and may provide additional information orally upon request.
Option C: The controller shall provide the information only electronically, without any written documentation.
Option D: The controller shall not provide any information to the data subject under Articles 13 and 14.

Question: Under what circumstances can a controller refuse to act on a request from a data subject for exercising their rights under Articles 15 to 22?
Option A: The controller can refuse to act on any request from a data subject.
Option B: The controller can refuse to act on a request if they demonstrate that they are not in a position to identify the data subject.
Option C: The controller can refuse to act on a request if it is manifestly unfounded or excessive.
Option D: The controller can refuse to act on a request if it is received more than once.

Question: What is the maximum period within which a controller shall provide information on action taken on a request under Articles 15 to 22?
When can a controller request additional information to confirm the identity of the data subject making a request?
Option A: Only when the request is made electronically
Option B: Only when the request is received by mail
Option C: Only when the controller has doubts concerning the identity of the data subject

Question: In cases where requests from a data subject are manifestly unfounded or excessive, what options does the controller have?
Option A: The controller can only refuse to act on the request
Option B: The controller can charge a reasonable fee taking into account the administrative costs
Option C: The controller can provide the information free of charge
Option D: The controller can only provide a summary of the information

Question: When collecting personal data from a data subject, what information must the controller provide at the time of obtaining the data?
Option B: The purposes of processing, legal basis, and identity of the controller
Option C: The right to withdraw consent and the recipients of the personal data
Option D: The period for which the personal data will be stored

Question: Under what circumstances does the controller not have to provide the information referred to in paragraphs 1, 2, and 3 of the GDPR?
Option A: When the data subject requests it
Option B: When the data subject has not provided the information voluntarily
Option C: When the data subject already has the information
Option D: When the controller intends to further process the personal data

Question: What information must the controller provide when processing personal data based on point (a) of Article 6(1) or point (a) of Article 9(2)?
Option A: The existence of the right to withdraw consent at any time
Option B: The right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority
Option C: The periods for which the personal data will be stored
Option D: The recipients or categories of recipients of the personal data

Question: What is the purpose of providing extra information to ensure fair and transparent processing?
Option A: To inform the data subject of the legal basis for processing
Option B: To provide the data subject with the right to withdraw consent
Option C: To ensure that the data subject has the necessary information to make informed decisions

Question: When intending to further process personal data for a purpose other than that for which the data were collected, what must the controller provide to the data subject prior to that further processing?
Option A: The identity and contact details of the data protection officer
Option B: The purposes of processing and any relevant further information
Option C: The right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority
Option D: The period for which the personal data will be stored

Question: What information must a controller provide to the data subject in respect of the categories of personal data concerned, if those data are not obtained from the data subject?
Option A: The legal basis for processing and the period for which the data will be stored
Option B: The purpose of processing, the categories of personal data concerned, and the recipients or categories of recipients of the data
Option C: The identity of the data protection officer and the contact details of the controller
Option D: The right to request rectification or erasure of personal data

Question: According to Article 15(3) of the GDPR, when a data subject makes a request to access their personal data, in which of the following formats should the controller provide the information unless otherwise requested by the data subject?
Option B: In a commonly used electronic format
Option C: In a format determined by the controller
Option D: In a format that is not electronic

Question: Which of the following rights is NOT included in the information that the controller must provide to the data subject, according to Article 15 of the GDPR?
Option D: The right to lodge a complaint with the supervisory authority

Question: According to Article 15(1) of the GDPR, what is the right of the data subject in relation to the controller's processing of personal data?
What is the controller allowed to charge a fee for in relation to a data subject's right to obtain a copy of their personal data, according to Article 15(3) of the GDPR?
Option C: The costs of providing the information
Option D: The costs of transferring the data

Question: What must the controller inform the data subject of when personal data are transferred to a third country or international organisation, according to Article 46 of the GDPR?
Option B: The categories of personal data concerned
Option C: The appropriate safeguards relating to the transfer
Option D: The recipients or categories of recipient involved

Question: What does the data subject have the right to obtain from the controller under Article 16 GDPR?
What must the controller consider when processing personal data under Article 16 GDPR?
Option A: Only the purpose of the processing
Option B: Only the accuracy of the personal data
Option C: The purposes of the processing and the accuracy of the personal data
Option D: The source of the personal data

Question: Which of the following is NOT a possibility for the data subject to have incomplete personal data completed under Article 16 GDPR?
Option C: By obtaining a confirmation from third parties
Option D: By requiring the controller to generate new data

Question: What is the timeframe for the controller to provide rectification of inaccurate personal data under Article 16 GDPR?
Option A: Within a reasonable period of time

Question: What is the data subject entitled to when requesting rectification of inaccurate personal data under Article 16 GDPR?
Option A: Only partial correction of personal data

Question: When is a controller obliged to erase personal data without undue delay, according to Article 17 GDPR?
Option A: When the data subject withdraws consent, and there is no other legal ground for processing.
Option B: When the data subject objects to processing, and there are no overriding legitimate grounds for processing.
Option C: When the data are no longer necessary in relation to the purposes for which they were collected or otherwise processed.
Option D: When the data are processed in the public interest or for scientific research purposes.

Question: What is the reason for which paragraphs 1 and 2 of Article 17 GDPR do not apply?
Option A: For exercising the right of freedom of expression and information.
Option B: For compliance with legal obligations under Union or Member State law.
Option C: For archiving purposes in the public interest.
Option D: For the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims.

Question: When is the controller required to inform other controllers of the erasure of personal data, according to Article 17(2) GDPR?
Option A: When the data are collected in relation to the offer of information society services.
Option B: When the personal data have been unlawfully processed.
Option C: When the controller has made the personal data public.
Option D: When the data subject withdraws consent.

Question: What is the purpose for which the processing of personal data is exempt from the obligation to erase, according to Article 17(3)(c) GDPR?
Option A: For the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims.
Option B: For archiving purposes in the public interest.
Option D: For reasons of public interest in the area of public health.

Question: In what circumstances is the controller exempt from the obligation to erase personal data, according to Article 17(3)(e) GDPR?
Option A: When the personal data have been collected in relation to the offer of information society services.
Option B: When the data subject objects to processing, and there are no overriding legitimate grounds for processing.
Option C: When the personal data are no longer necessary in relation to the purposes for which they were collected or otherwise processed.
Option D: When the controller is subject to a legal obligation under Union or Member State law.

Question: What are the reasons that justify a data subject's right to restrict processing under GDPR Article 18?
Option A: Only when personal data is contested by the data subject or processing is unlawful.
Option B: When the data subject contests the accuracy of personal data, opposes erasure of personal data, or requires personal data for legal claims.
Option C: When the controller no longer needs personal data or the data subject objects to processing.
Option D: Only when the data subject is a minor or has limited capacity.

Question: What can processing restricted under GDPR Article 18, paragraph 1, be used for?
Option A: Only with the data subject's consent, for marketing purposes, or for data sharing.
Option B: With the data subject's consent, for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims, for the protection of rights of another natural or legal person, or for reasons of important public interest.
Option C: Always with the data subject's consent, and never for legal claims or rights protection.
Option D: Only for the protection of rights of another natural or legal person or for reasons of important public interest.

Question: What obligation does a controller have when a data subject has obtained restriction of processing?
Option B: Inform the data subject before lifting the restriction.
Option C: Seek permission from the data subject before lifting the restriction.

Question: Can a controller restrict processing without a data subject's consent under GDPR Article 18?
Option C: Only when a data subject contests the accuracy of personal data.
Option D: Only when a data subject opposes erasure of personal data.

Question: For how long can a controller restrict processing under GDPR Article 18, paragraph 1, while verifying the accuracy of personal data?
Option A: Until the data subject withdraws their objection.
Option B: Until the data subject requests erasure.
Option C: Until the data subject confirms correctness of personal data.
Option D: For a period enabling the controller to verify the accuracy of the personal data.

Question: When a controller rectifies, erases, or restricts personal data, what is the obligation regarding notification to recipients?
Option A: Notify only those recipients who have a legitimate interest in the data.
Option B: Notify all recipients to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless impossible or disproportionate effort is required.
Option C: Notify only the data subjects, as they have the right to know about the changes.
Option D: Do not notify recipients, as this is not mentioned in the GDPR.

Question: According to the GDPR, under what circumstances is it possible to waive the obligation to notify recipients to whom personal data have been disclosed?
Option A: When the processing is based on consent and the data subject requests it.
Option B: When the rectification, erasure, or restriction is carried out to ensure data integrity.
Option C: When it proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort.
Option D: When the data subject has been informed about the recipients.

Question: Which of the following is NOT a scenario where notification to recipients may not be possible or involve disproportionate effort?
Option A: When a large number of recipients need to be notified.
Option B: When the processing involves sensitive personal data.
Option C: When the controller has notified all recipients before.
Option D: When the data controller has not collected the necessary contact information.

Question: According to the GDPR, who can request information about the recipients to whom personal data have been disclosed?
Option A: Only the data subjects who have filed a complaint with the supervisory authority.
Option B: Only the data subjects whose data have been restricted or erased.
Option C: The data subjects who have the right to access their personal data.
Option D: The data subjects in all situations where their personal data have been disclosed.

Question: What is the controller's obligation regarding informing the data subject about the recipients if the data subject requests it?
Option A: The controller must provide the list of recipients in a separate notification.
Option B: The controller must provide the list of recipients in the same notification as the rectification or erasure.
Option C: The controller must only inform the data subject if the data was disclosed to third parties.
Option D: The controller must notify the data subject only in cases where the data was disclosed to third-party recipients.

Question: What is the condition for the data subject's right to data portability?
Option A: The processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest.
Option B: The processing is based on Article 6(1) (b) and carried out by non-automated means.
Option C: The processing is based on consent or a contract and carried out by automated means.
Option D: The processing is necessary for the exercise of official authority vested in the controller.

Question: What is the consequence of exercising the right to data portability?
Option A: The right to erasure is granted.
Option B: The right to data portability is revoked.
Option C: The exercise of the right is without prejudice to Article 17.
Option D: The data subject's rights and freedoms are compromised.

Question: What is the format in which the data subject can receive their personal data?
Can the data subject request direct transmission of their personal data from one controller to another?
Option B: No, unless the processing is based on Article 6(1) (b)
Option C: Only if the processing is carried out by non-automated means
Option D: Only if the processing is based on consent

Question: What is the condition under which a data controller may continue processing personal data after a data subject objects?
Option A: After providing a valid consent to the data subject
Option B: If the controller demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing
Option C: If the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest
Option D: If the data subject provides a specific reason for the objection

Question: According to GDPR, what must the controller do when exercising the right to object for direct marketing purposes?
Option A: Notify the data subject of the objection
Option B: Stop processing the personal data immediately
Option C: No longer process the personal data unless necessary for legal claims
Option D: Verify the data subject's identity before processing

Question: Which of the following is a exception to the right to object to scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes?
Option A: If the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest
Option B: If the data subject provides a specific reason for the objection
Option C: If the controller uses anonymized data
Option D: If the research is entirely conducted offline

Question: How should the right to object be explicitly brought to the attention of the data subject at the latest?
Option B: At the time of the first communication with the data subject
Option C: When the personal data is actually processed
Option D: Only after a data breach occurs

Question: What is the right to object defined as in the context of the use of information society services?
Option A: The right to request a copy of the data
Option B: The right to correct personal data
Option C: The right to object to processing by automated means
Option D: The right to delete personal data

Question: When does the right of a data subject not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning him or her or similarly significantly affects him or her not apply?
Option A: When the decision is authorized by Union or Member State law and lays down suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests.
Option B: When the decision is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between the data subject and a data controller.
Option C: When the decision is based on the data subject's explicit consent.

Question: What is the purpose of restricting the scope of obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22 and Article 34 of the GDPR, as referred to in Article 23 of the GDPR?
Option A: To prioritize the interests of data controllers and processors over those of data subjects
Option B: To ensure the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms in a democratic society
Option C: To permit data controllers and processors to engage in any processing activity without restrictions
Option D: To require data subjects to consent to all data processing activities

Question: According to Article 25 of the GDPR, what is the primary objective of the controller when implementing technical and organisational measures?
Option A: To ensure the lawful transfer of personal data to third countries.
Option B: To ensure and demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with the GDPR.
Option C: To implement data protection by design and default principles.
Option D: To implement data protection impact assessments for high-risk processing activities.

Question: What should the controller include in the technical and organisational measures implemented to ensure GDPR compliance, if proportionate in relation to processing activities?
According to the text, what may be used as an element to demonstrate compliance with the obligations of the controller?
Option B: Adherence to approved codes of conduct and approved certification mechanisms.
Option C: Only adherence to approved codes of conduct.
Option D: Neither approved codes of conduct nor approved certification mechanisms.

Question: According to Article 25(1) of the GDPR, what factors should the controller consider when implementing technical and organisational measures?
Option A: The controller's financial budget and market competition.
Option B: The nature, scope, context, and purposes of processing, as well as the risks of varying likelihood and severity for the rights and freedoms of natural persons.
Option C: The number of employees and organisational structure of the controller.
Option D: The type and importance of the personal data processed.

Question: How often should the controller review and update the technical and organisational measures implemented to ensure GDPR compliance?
Option A: Only when new data protection laws are introduced.
Option B: Only when the processing activities change.

Question: What is the primary goal of implementing technical and organisational measures according to Article 25 of the GDPR?
Option A: To provide evidence of compliance with GDPR requirements
Option B: To ensure that only personal data necessary for each specific purpose is processed
Option D: To collect an indefinite number of personal data

Question: Which of the following is NOT a consideration the controller must take into account when implementing technical and organisational measures?
Option A: The state of the art and the cost of implementation
Option B: The nature, scope, context and purposes of processing
Option C: The likelihood and severity of risks for rights and freedoms of natural persons
Option D: The culture and traditions of the country of processing

Question: What is the purpose of ensuring that personal data are not made accessible without the individualâ€™s intervention to an indefinite number of natural persons?
Option A: To reduce the risk of data breaches
Option B: To comply with the data minimisation principle
Option C: To protect the rights of data subjects
Option D: To increase the cost of implementation

Question: What principle is considered in the design of technical and organisational measures according to Article 25 of the GDPR?
What happens when two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing?
Option A: They become separate controllers with distinct responsibilities.
Option B: They are jointly responsible for compliance with the obligations under the GDPR.
Option C: They must notify the competent supervisory authority of their joint decision.
Option D: They can opt out of the arrangement and continue to process data separately.

Question: Where must the representative of the controller or processor be established under Article 3(2) of the GDPR?
Option B: In the Member State where the controller or processor is established
Option C: In one of the Member States where the data subjects whose personal data are processed are
Option D: In a Member State of the controller's or processor's choice

Question: According to Article 28(1), what does the controller do before engaging a processor?
Option A: Conducts a thorough background check on the processor
Option B: Reviews the processor's data protection policies
Option C: Uses only processors providing sufficient guarantees to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures
Option D: Provides detailed instructions for the processor's operations

Question: What is the processor required to do if it believes an instruction from the controller infringes the Regulation or other Union or Member State data protection provisions?
Option D: Seek guidance from a supervisory authority

Question: Who is responsible for data protection obligations if a processor engages another processor to perform specific processing activities on behalf of the controller?
Option A: The initial processor and the other processor

Question: What happens if a processor infringes this Regulation by determining the purposes and means of processing, according to Article 29(7)?
Option A: The processor is exempt from liability
Option B: The processor is considered a controller in respect of that processing
Option C: The processor is subject to a fine
Option D: The processor must notify the controller immediately

Question: In accordance with GDPR, what is the condition under which a processor can process personal data without instructions from the controller?
Option A: When the processing is necessary for the purposes of the controller's legitimate interests.
Option B: When required to do so by Union or Member State law.
Option C: When the data subject has given explicit consent.
Option D: When the processor-dealer is a part of the same corporate group as the controller.

Question: According to Article 30 of the GDPR, what must be included in a controller's record of processing activities?
Option A: A comprehensive list of all data subjects
Option B: A description of the categories of personal data and recipients
Option C: The name and contact details of the controller and the data protection officer
Option D: An evaluation of the processing activities' compliance with Article 6

Question: Which of the following is an exemption from the obligations in paragraphs 1 and 2 of Article 30?
Option A: Enterprises or organisations with more than 250 employees
Option B: Enterprises or organisations employing fewer than 250 persons
Option C: Controllers processing data occasional and not likely to result in a risk to data subjects' rights
Option D: Controllers processing special categories of data

Question: What must be included in a processor's record of processing activities under Article 30?
Option A: A description of the categories of data subjects and personal data
Option B: The name and contact details of the processor and the data protection officer
Option C: A general description of the technical and organisational security measures
Option D: The categories of processing carried out on behalf of each controller

Question: In what format must the records referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 of Article 30 be kept?
Option B: In writing, including in electronic form
Option D: In both written and electronic form

Question: According to Article 30, to whom must the controller or processor make the record available on request?
When a supervisory authority requests cooperation, what is the obligation of the controller, the processor, and their representatives?
Option A: To provide the requested information only
Option B: To cooperate only if the request is related to a data breach
Option C: To cooperate fully in the performance of the supervisory authority's tasks
Option D: To decline the request if it infringes on national security

Question: When assessing the appropriate level of security for processing personal data, account shall be taken in particular of the risks that are presented by processing, in particular from which types of damage?
Option A: Accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to personal data
Option B: Damage caused by natural disasters or equipment failure

Question: According to Article [RECOVERY TIME Objective] of the GDPR, the ability to restore the availability and access to personal data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident is critical.

According to the GDPR, the controller and processor shall take steps to ensure that any natural person acting under the authority of the controller or the processor who has access to personal data does not process them except on instructions from the controller, unless he or she is required to do so by which laws?
Option A: Union or Member State data protection law
Option B: Union or Member State information security law
Option C: Union or Member State employee law
Option D: Union or Member State technology law

Question: According to Article 33 of the GDPR, what is the maximum timeframe for notifying the supervisory authority in case of a personal data breach?
What should the notification referred to in paragraph 1 of Article 33 of the GDPR at least include?
Option A: A detailed explanation of the technical measures taken to prevent future breaches
Option B: The name and contact details of the data protection officer or other contact point where more information can be obtained
Option C: A copy of the breached personal data
Option D: A list of all affected data subjects

Question: In case the notification to the supervisory authority is not made within 72 hours, what must it be accompanied by?
Option C: A technical assessment of the breach
Option D: A list of all affected data subjects

Question: When is it permissible to provide the information required in Article 33 of the GDPR in phases?
Option B: When it is not possible to provide the information at the same time
Option C: When the breach is affecting sensitive data
Option D: When the breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of natural persons

Question: What does the controller have to document according to Article 33 of the GDPR?
Option A: Only the measures taken to mitigate the breach's adverse effects
Option B: A detailed analysis of the breach's root causes
Option C: The facts relating to the personal data breach, its effects, and the remedial action taken
Option D: A list of all affected data subjects

Question: What is the primary purpose of communicating a personal data breach to the data subject, according to Article 33 of the GDPR?
Option A: To punish the data controller for the breach
Option B: To provide information on how to mitigate the harmful effects of the breach
Option C: To ensure transparency and notify the data subject without undue delay if the breach is likely to result in a high risk to their rights and freedoms

Question: According to Article 33 of the GDPR, which of the following is NOT a valid condition for not communicating a personal data breach to the data subject?
Option A: The controller has implemented appropriate technical and organisational protection measures, and those measures were applied to the personal data affected by the personal data breach
Option B: The controller has taken subsequent measures which ensure that the high risk to the rights and freedoms of data subjects is no longer likely to materialise
Option C: The controller has inadequate resources to handle the breach

Question: In the event that the controller has implemented appropriate technical and organisational protection measures, and those measures were applied to the personal data affected by the personal data breach, would the controller still be required to communicate the breach to the data subject?
Option A: Yes, the controller must always inform the data subject
Option B: No, the controller is exempt from informing the data subject
Option C: The controller may choose not to inform the data subject, but must inform the supervisory authority
Option D: The controller must inform the supervisory authority, but not the data subject

Question: According to Article 33 of the GDPR, what should the communication to the data subject contain, in addition to the nature of the personal data breach?
Option A: A detailed list of affected data subjects
Option B: Information on the measures taken to prevent similar breaches in the future
Option C: Information on the measures referred to in points (b), (c) and (d) of Article 33(3)
Option D: A statement of the controller's liability for the breach

Question: Which supervisory authority may require a controller to communicate a personal data breach to the data subject, according to Article 33 of the GDPR?
Option C: The data subject's national supervisory authority
Option D: The relevant national data protection authority

Question: Under what circumstances is a data protection impact assessment exempt from the requirement to carry out a review of processing activities?
Option A: When the processing is solely based on explicit consent.
Option B: When the processing has a legal basis in Union law or the law of the Member State.
Option C: When the processing is performed by a small-scale organization.
Option D: When the processing is solely based on automation.

Question: What must a data protection impact assessment contain at a minimum?
Option A: An analysis of the necessity and proportionality of the processing operations.
Option B: A description of the envisaged processing operations and purposes, as well as a risk assessment.
Option C: A review of the records of processing activities.
Option D: A justification of the legitimate interest pursued by the controller.

Question: What is the purpose of establishing and making public lists of processing operations that are subject or not subject to a data protection impact assessment?
Option A: To publicly shame organizations that fail to carry out DPIAs.
Option B: To provide transparency for data subjects about the types of processing operations that require DPIAs.
Option C: To promote consistency among Member States regarding DPIAs.
Option D: To facilitate data protection impact assessments through standardized templates.

Question: What should the controller do when seeking the views of data subjects or their representatives on intended processing?
Option A: Ignore their views if they conflict with the controller's goals.
Option B: Give equal weight to all views without considering the protection of commercial or public interests.
Option C: Seek views without prejudice to the protection of commercial or public interests or the security of processing operations.

Question: What should the controller do if the processing operations have changed, representing a different risk?
Option A: Ignore the risk and continue processing as before.
Option B: Interrupt processing until a new data protection impact assessment is carried out.
Option C: Perform a review to assess if processing is performed in accordance with the data protection impact assessment at least when there is a change of the risk represented by processing operations.
Option D: Report the change to the supervisory authority.

Question: When should a controller consult the supervisory authority prior to processing, as per Article 36?
Option A: When the processing is within a group of undertakings
Option B: When the processing involves a data protection impact assessment under Article 35
Option C: When the processing is for the performance of a task carried out by the controller in the public interest
Option D: When the processing is for the purpose of social protection and public health

Question: In accordance with Article 38 of the GDPR, when must a controller or processor designate a data protection officer?
Option A: When the processing involves personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences.
Option B: When the controller or processor processes special categories of data on a large scale.
Option C: When the processing requires regular and systematic monitoring of data subjects on a large scale.
Option D: When the controller or processor is a public authority or body, except for courts acting in their judicial capacity.

Question: What is the condition under which a group of undertakings can appoint a single data protection officer?
Option A: The group of undertakings must be located in the same country.
Option B: A data protection officer is easily accessible from each establishment.
Option C: The group of undertakings must have a single physical location.
Option D: The group of undertakings must have less than 50 employees.

Question: According to Article 39 of the GDPR, on what criteria should the data protection officer be designated?
Option A: Based on the employee's tenure with the controller or processor.
Option B: Based on professional qualities and expert knowledge of data protection law and practices.
Option C: Based on the employee's role in the organization.
Option D: Based on the employee's education level.

Question: Can a data protection officer act on behalf of associations and other bodies representing controllers or processors?
Option A: Yes, and they are required by law to do so.
Option B: Yes, but only in specific circumstances.
Option C: No, they are not allowed to act on their behalf.
Option D: It is not specified in the GDPR.

Question: Who should the controller or processor publish the contact details of the data protection officer and communicate them to?
Option C: The employees and customers of the controller or processor.

Question: According to Article 38 of the GDPR, who shall ensure that the data protection officer does not receive any instructions regarding the exercise of his/her tasks?
Option A: The data protection officer's direct supervisor
Option B: The highest management level of the controller or processor

Question: What is the primary responsibility of the data protection officer when performing their tasks?
Option A: To ensure the implementation of data protection policies and procedures.
Option B: To monitor the supervisory authority's actions and provide advice where requested.
Option C: To investigate reports of data breaches and take corrective action.
Option D: To inform and advise the controller or processor and their employees of their obligations under the GDPR.

Question: According to Article 37, what is the data protection officer required to take into account when performing their tasks?
Option A: The legislative requirements and technical specifications relevant to the processing.
Option B: The risk associated with processing operations, taking into account the nature, scope, context, and purposes of processing.
Option C: The number of data subjects whose personal data is being processed.
Option D: The type of data being processed, such as names, addresses, and phone numbers.

Question: What is the data protection officer's role in relation to the supervisory authority, as referred to in Article 36?
Option A: To submit reports on data breaches to the supervisory authority.
Option B: To cooperate with the supervisory authority and act as a contact point for issues related to processing.
Option C: To represent the supervisory authority in appeals against fines or penalties.
Option D: To investigate complaints filed with the supervisory authority.

Question: What is one of the tasks mentioned in Article 37 that the data protection officer may be required to perform?
Option B: Conducting audits to ensure compliance with data protection provisions.
Option C: Providing advice on the processing of sensitive personal data.
Option D: Monitoring the performance of data protection impact assessments.

Question: What is the data protection officer required to do when providing advice on data protection impact assessments, as referred to in Article 35?
Option A: To conduct an independent review of the assessment.
Option B: To provide an opinion on the assessment's findings and recommendations.
Option C: To certify the assessment's accuracy and completeness.
Option D: To intervene in the assessment's findings and recommendations.

Question: When preparing a code of conduct, what aspects shall Associations and other bodies representing categories of controllers or processors take into account, according to Article 40(1)?
Option B: Specific features of the various processing sectors and the specific needs of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises
Option D: Processing activities in several Member States

Question: Can a code of conduct approved pursuant to Article 40(5) be adhered to by controllers or processors that are not subject to this Regulation?
Option B: Only if they are small businesses
Option C: Yes, with binding and enforceable commitments to apply appropriate safeguards

Question: Who provides the opinion on whether a draft code, amendment or extension complies with GDPR Regulation, in the situation where the code relates to processing activities in several Member States?
How shall the Commission ensure publicity for approved codes that have been decided as having general validity?
Option A: By publishing them on its website
Option B: By sending a notification to all controllers and processors
Option C: By making them publicly available by way of appropriate means
Option D: By posting them on social media

Question: Who shall collate all approved codes of conduct, amendments and extensions and make them publicly available?
